Award.AwardTitle: Optogenetic Tools for Minimally Invasive Therapies

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1264975
Chow

The ability to rationally convert a microbial opsin pump into a channel would validate a fundamental hypothesis in ion channel structure-function, which states that a key difference between a pump and a channel is the existence of a gate that prevents backflow of ions by passive conductance and enables active ion translocation against large gradients. This biophysical feat of rational conversion by protein engineering would be the first of its kind. Furthermore, while the activity-dependent safety of neural silencing by proton and chloride pumps has been evaluated in the literature, the creation of optogenetic reagents specifically for the purpose of activity-dependent safety is novel. Moreover, the translationally focused goal of engineering a calcium-free channelrhodopsin to reduce risk of excito-toxicity is in fact opposite to ongoing efforts in the field, which seek to augment calciumconductance to increase sensitivity. The creation of reagents, whose molecular properties are tailored for translational purposes, would represent a new direction in optogenetic reagent development, which to date have focused on pushing the limits of microbial opsin photocurrent magnitude, kinetics, and spectral properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall goal of this project was to engineer optogenetic reagents for the purpose of employing them in minimally invasive therapies via the remote optical control of cellular physiology. We created red light-absorbing cation channels (channelrhodopsins) and chloride pumps (halorhodopsins) for optical depolarization and hyperpolarization of excitable cells, respectively, as well variants with decreased risk of activity dependent toxicity (reduction of channelrhodopsin calcium photocurrents). In terms of broader impacts, because efficient propagation of red light through tissue effectively increases optogenetic sensitivity in a practical setting (by decreasing the necessary input irradiance), the effective sensitivity increase improves the ability for technology users to control the physiology of large tissue volumes, and enhances the prospects for minimally invasive optogenetic treatments by potentially non-invasive stimulation. In terms of intellectual merits, these red light-sensitive opsins, which were gained through a combination of surveying genomic diversity and molecular engineering efforts, pushed spectral boundaries amongst known photosensory proteins of related physiological function.

Moreover, numerous new technologies and resources of importance were developed in support of this project. For example, we created compact far-red fluorescent proteins using de novo protein design (i.e. proteins of completely artificial origin). This feat has intellectual merit because de novo proteins have not previously been functionally expressed in mammalian cells, and likewise, has broader impact because of the universal importance of small fluorescent proteins in cellular imaging (here, one-third the size of canonical ones). In another example of broader impact, we developed custom bioinformatics algorithms to create a database that annotated thousands of new photosensory proteins, thus expanding the known signaling diversity by which lower organisms respond to the sensory cue of light, as well providing new molecular templates for engineering optogenetic tools. We anticipate that these works will benefit bioengineering, biomedical sciences, and organismal biology alike.
